Mr. Howard S. Frazier
Suite 726 Bond Building
Washington 5, D. C.
Dear Mr. Frazier:
This is in response to your request for information about
George A. Bernstein in connection with his application for a
position as station or sales manager, program director or
assistant to executive, through your Broadcasters Executive
Placement Service.
During three of the four years which I served as president of
the Cooperative Broadcasting Association operating Radio Station
WCFM, George Bernstein served as our general manager, and since
it was a small station, also had over-all responsibility for sales,
programming and other operations, so that he has become well-qualified
in each of those fields.
As you know, the FM section of the radio industry has been a
stepchild, and any success achieved in that field takes on added
importance because of that fact. WCFM also had the handicap of
being a forthright liberal station, and its cooperative ownership
my 1 o h vconfused some of the commercial people in the field.
In spite of these three factors which might normally be interpreted
as handicaps in the industry, Mr. Bernstein was successful in raising
the stationfs revenue from s^800 a month to over 04,000 a month
during that period. At the same time he cut operating expenses from
08,000 a month to $5,000 a month without sacrificing any of the
excellent programming for which the station has now become famous.
Under his initiative the Cooperative Broadcasting Association
sponsored the organization of the WCFM Recording Company which
recorded and marketed its first half-dozen important recordings
under Mr. Bernstein*s management. The undertaking was doubly
important because it was the only record company of its kind in
Washington, and on the creative side, made it possible for
Washington musicians to have access to recording facilities. Of
particular interest was the fact that a number of the recordings
have been made by the National Gallery of Art Symphony Orchestra
under the direction of Richard Bales. It was Mr. Bernstein who
made arrangements for this recording.
Mr. Bernstein left WCFM to become assistant to the general manager
of the Peopleâ€™s Broadcasting Company in Columbus, Ohio, at a
substantial increase in salary. You vmdoubtedly have further references
from him in regard to that phase of his activities.
Sincerely yours,
THE COOPERATIVE LEAGUE
/s/Wallace J. Campbell
